content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays a single, irregularly shaped fragment of tissue. It appears to be composed of fibrofatty tissue with multifocal, more cellular, basophilic (purple) areas and large, pale, somewhat cystic-appearing spaces. It does not have the typical ovoid shape or architecture of a well-defined lymph node. It looks more like a piece of soft tissue, which in the context of a colorectal cancer resection, would be searched for lymph nodes or tumor deposits.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I would zoom into this area because it represents an interface between the paler, looser connective tissue and a more densely cellular, basophilic nodular structure. Pathologists are trained to investigate areas with increased cellularity or distinct architectural changes, as these are prime locations to find pathology, such as a small lymph node, a tumor deposit, or another type of lesion. This specific area represents a focal point of interest that requires high-power examination for definitive characterization. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, on the right, there is a well-circumscribed epithelial proliferation characterized by nests of small basaloid cells and extensive areas of anucleated eosinophilic cells with distinct cell borders, known as "ghost" or "shadow" cells. This morphology is pathognomonic for a pilomatricoma, a benign adnexal tumor of hair matrix origin. The surrounding tissue consists of fibrous stroma, adipose tissue, and congested blood vessels. My impression is that this is an incidental finding of a pilomatricoma, likely from a skin/subcutaneous tissue sample taken during the surgery. There is no evidence of metastatic adenocarcinoma or lymph node tissue in this specific field of view.
